Options.Description:
Start directly in fullscreen (disabled by default).
Run INTRO and see Special Keys for window control hotkeys.
Number of display to use; values depend on OS and user settings (0 by default).
What resolution to use for fullscreen: 'original', 'desktop' or a fixed size, e.g. 1024x768 ('desktop' by default).

Set window size when running in windowed mode: default: Select the best option based on your environment and other settings. small, medium, large (s, m, l): Size the window relative to the desktop. <custom>: Scale the window to the given dimensions in WxH format. For example: 1024x768.

EnumValues.Description: Select the best option based on your environment and other settings.

Options.Description: Set the viewport size (drawable area) within the window/screen: fit: Fit the viewport to the available window/screen (default). <custom>: Limit the viewport within to a custom resolution or percentage of the desktop. Specified in WxH, N%, N.M%. Examples: 960x720 or 50%

EnumValues.Description: Fit the viewport to the available window/screen (default).

Options.Description: Set initial window position when running in windowed mode: auto: Let the window manager decide the position (default). <custom>: Set window position in X,Y format. For example: 250,100 0,0 is the top-left corner of the screen.

EnumValues.Description: Let the window manager decide the position (default).

Options.Description: Enable window decorations in windowed mode (enabled by default).
Set the transparency of the DOSBox Staging screen (0 by default). From 0 (no transparency) to 90 (high transparency).

Set the host's refresh rate: auto: Use SDI rates, or VRR rates when fullscreen on a high-refresh display (default). sdi: Use serial device interface (SDI) rates, without further adjustment. vrr: Deduct 3 Hz from the reported rate (best practice for VRR displays). <custom>: Specify a custom rate as an integer or decimal Hz value (23.000 is the allowed minimum).

EnumValues.Description: Use SDI rates, or VRR rates when fullscreen on a high-refresh display (default).
Use serial device interface (SDI) rates, without further adjustment.
Deduct 3 Hz from the reported rate (best practice for VRR displays).

Options.Description: Set the host video driver's vertical synchronization (vsync) mode: auto: Limit vsync to beneficial cases, such as when using an interpolating VRR display in fullscreen (default). on: Enable vsync. This can prevent tearing in some games but will impact performance or drop frames when the DOS rate exceeds the host rate (e.g. 70 Hz DOS rate vs 60 Hz host rate). off: Attempt to disable vsync to allow quicker frame presentation at the risk of tearing in some games. yield: Let the host's video driver control video synchronization. Possible values: auto, on, off, yield.

EnumValues.Description: Limit vsync to beneficial cases, such as when using an interpolating VRR display in fullscreen (default).
Enable vsync. This can prevent tearing in some games but will impact performance or drop frames when the DOS rate exceeds the host rate (e.g. 70 Hz DOS rate vs 60 Hz host rate).
Attempt to disable vsync to allow quicker frame presentation at the risk of tearing in some games.
Let the host's video driver control video synchronization.

Options.Description: Number of microseconds to allow rendering to block before skipping the next frame. For example, a value of 7000 is roughly half the frame time at 70 Hz. 0 disables this and will always render (default).

Select the frame presentation mode: auto: Intelligently time and drop frames to prevent emulation stalls, based on host and DOS frame rates (default). cfr: Always present DOS frames at a constant frame rate. vfr: Always present changed DOS frames at a variable frame rate. Possible values: auto, cfr, vfr.

EnumValues.Description: Intelligently time and drop frames to prevent emulation stalls, based on host and DOS frame rates (default).
Always present DOS frames at a constant frame rate.
Always present changed DOS frames at a variable frame rate.

Options.Description: Video system to use for output ('opengl' by default). 'texture' and 'opengl' use bilinear interpolation, 'texturenb' and 'openglnb' use nearest-neighbour (no-bilinear). Some shaders require bilinear interpolation, making that the safest choice. Possible values: texture, texturenb, opengl, openglnb. Deprecated values: openglpp, surface, texturepp.
Render driver to use in 'texture' output mode ('auto' by default). Use 'texture_renderer = auto' for an automatic choice. Possible values: auto, opengl, opengles2, software.
Keep the console open if an error has occurred (enabled by default).

Priority levels to apply when active and inactive, respectively. ('auto auto' by default) 'auto' lets the host operating system manage the priority. Possible values: auto, lowest, lower, normal, higher, highest.
Mute the sound when the window is inactive (disabled by default).
Pause emulation when the window is inactive (disabled by default).

File used to load/save the key/event mappings. Pre-configured maps are bundled in the 'resources/mapperfiles' directory. They can be loaded by name, for example: mapperfile = xbox/xenon2.map Note: The --resetmapper command line flag only deletes the default mapperfile.

Use 'allow' or 'block' to override the SDL_VIDEO_ALLOW_SCREENSAVER environment variable which usually blocks the OS screensaver while the emulator is running ('auto' by default). Possible values: auto, allow, block.

Select a language to use: 'de', 'en', 'es', 'fr', 'it', 'nl', 'pl', or 'ru' (unset by default; this defaults to English) Notes: - This setting will override the 'LANG' environment variable, if set. - The bundled 'resources/translations' directory with the executable holds these files. Please keep it along-side the executable to support this feature.

Set the video adapter or machine to emulate: hercules: Hercules Graphics Card (HGC) (see 'monochrome_palette'). cga_mono: CGA adapter connected to a monochrome monitor (see 'monochrome_palette'). cga: IBM Color Graphics Adapter (CGA). Also enables composite video emulation (see [composite] section). pcjr: An IBM PCjr machine. Also enables PCjr sound and composite video emulation (see [composite] section). tandy: A Tandy 1000 machine with TGA graphics. Also enables Tandy sound and composite video emulation (see [composite] section). ega: IBM Enhanced Graphics Adapter (EGA). svga_paradise: Paradise PVGA1A SVGA card (no VESA VBE; 512K vmem by default, can be set to 256K or 1MB with 'vmemsize'). This is the closest to IBM's original VGA adapter. svga_et3000: Tseng Labs ET3000 SVGA card (no VESA VBE; fixed 512K vmem). svga_et4000: Tseng Labs ET4000 SVGA card (no VESA VBE; 1MB vmem by default, can be set to 256K or 512K with 'vmemsize'). svga_s3: S3 Trio64 (VESA VBE 2.0; 4MB vmem by default, can be set to 512K, 1MB, 2MB, or 8MB with 'vmemsize') (default) vesa_oldvbe: Same as 'svga_s3' but limited to VESA VBE 1.2. vesa_nolfb: Same as 'svga_s3' (VESA VBE 2.0), plus the "no linear framebuffer" hack (needed only by a few games). Possible values: hercules, cga_mono, cga, pcjr, tandy, ega, svga_s3, svga_et3000, svga_et4000, svga_paradise, vesa_nolfb, vesa_oldvbe. Deprecated values: vgaonly.

EnumValues.Description: Hercules Graphics Card (HGC) (see 'monochrome_palette').
CGA adapter connected to a monochrome monitor (see 'monochrome_palette').
IBM Color Graphics Adapter (CGA). Also enables composite video emulation (see [composite] section).
An IBM PCjr machine. Also enables PCjr sound and composite video emulation (see [composite] section).
A Tandy 1000 machine with TGA graphics. Also enables Tandy sound and composite video emulation (see [composite] section).
IBM Enhanced Graphics Adapter (EGA).
Paradise PVGA1A SVGA card (no VESA VBE; 512K vmem by default, can be set to 256K or 1MB with 'vmemsize'). This is the closest to IBM's original VGA adapter.
Tseng Labs ET3000 SVGA card (no VESA VBE; fixed 512K vmem).
Tseng Labs ET4000 SVGA card (no VESA VBE; 1MB vmem by default, can be set to 256K or 512K with 'vmemsize').
S3 Trio64 (VESA VBE 2.0; 4MB vmem by default, can be set to 512K, 1MB, 2MB, or 8MB with 'vmemsize') (default)
Same as 'svga_s3' (VESA VBE 2.0), plus the "no linear framebuffer" hack (needed only by a few games).
Same as 'svga_s3' but limited to VESA VBE 1.2.

Options.Description: Amount of memory of the emulated machine has in MB (16 by default). Best leave at the default setting to avoid problems with some games, though a few games might require a higher value. There is generally no speed advantage when raising this value.

How software-corrupted memory chain blocks should be handled: repair: Repair (and report) faults using adjacent blocks (default). report: Report faults but otherwise proceed as-is. allow: Allow faults to go unreported (hardware behavior). deny: Quit (and report) when faults are detected. Possible values: repair, report, allow, deny.

Video memory in MB (1-8) or KB (256 to 8192). 'auto' uses the default for the selected video adapter ('auto' by default). See the 'machine' setting for the list of valid options per adapter. Possible values: auto, 1, 2, 4, 8, 256, 512, 1024, 2048, 4096, 8192.

Customize the emulated video mode's frame rate, in Hz: default: The DOS video mode determines the rate (recommended; default). host: Match the DOS rate to the host rate (see 'host_rate' setting). <value>: Sets the rate to an exact value, between 24.000 and 1000.000 (Hz). We recommend the 'default' rate; otherwise test and set on a per-game basis.

EnumValues.Description: The DOS video mode determines the rate (recommended; default).
Match the DOS rate to the host rate (see 'host_rate' setting).

Options.Description: Controls the selection of VESA 1.2 and 2.0 modes offered: compatible: A tailored selection that maximizes game compatibility. This is recommended along with 4 or 8 MB of video memory (default). halfline: Supports the low-resolution halfline VESA 2.0 mode used by Extreme Assault. Use this with 4 or 8 MB of video memory. fullline: Supports the low-resolution fullline VESA 2.0 mode used by Extreme Assault. Use this with 4 or 8 MB of video memory. all: All VESA modes supported by the selected video adapter. This is recommended along with 8 MB of video memory. Possible values: compatible, halfline, fullline, all.

EnumValues.Description: A tailored selection that maximizes game compatibility. This is recommended along with 4 or 8 MB of video memory (default).
Supports the low-resolution halfline VESA 2.0 mode used by Extreme Assault. Use this with 4 or 8 MB of video memory.
Supports the low-resolution fullline VESA 2.0 mode used by Extreme Assault. Use this with 4 or 8 MB of video memory.
All VESA modes supported by the selected video adapter. This is recommended along with 8 MB of video memory.

Options.Description: Use the 8-dot VGA font instead of the 9-dot MCGA font (disabled by default).
Enable speed hacks (enabled by default).
How autoexec sections are handled from multiple config files:

EnumValues.Description: Combine them into one big section (legacy behavior; default).
Merge them into one big section, but keep the original files separate.

Options.Description: Enable auto-mounting of drives (enabled by default).

Set the startup verbosity level: 0: Show only the DOSBox Staging logo (default). 1: Show the DOSBox Staging logo and version. 2: Show the DOSBox Staging logo, version, and configuration file information. 3: Show the DOSBox Staging logo, version, configuration file information, and the list of mounted drives. 4: Show the DOSBox Staging logo, version, configuration file information, the list of mounted drives, and the list of autoexec sections. 5: Show the DOSBox Staging logo, version, configuration file information, the list of mounted drives, the list of autoexec sections, and the list of loaded config files. Possible values: 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
Allow write access to files marked as read-only (disabled by default).
Enable shell configuration shortcuts (enabled by default).

Set the aspect ratio of the output window: auto: Use the aspect ratio of the DOS video mode (default). 4:3: Force a 4:3 aspect ratio. 16:9: Force a 16:9 aspect ratio. 16:10: Force a 16:10 aspect ratio. 5:4: Force a 5:4 aspect ratio. 1:1: Force a 1:1 aspect ratio. Possible values: auto, 4:3, 16:9, 16:10, 5:4, 1:1.
Enable integer scaling (disabled by default).

EnumValues.Description: 'vertical' mode auto-enabled for adaptive CRT shaders only, otherwise 'off' (default).
Constrain the vertical scaling factor to integer values within the viewport. This is the recommended setting when using CRT shaders to avoid uneven scanlines and unwanted interference artifacts.
Constrain the horizontal scaling factor to integer values within the viewport.
No integer scaling constraint is applied; the image fills the viewport according to the 'aspect' setting.

Options.Description: Set the palette for monochrome display emulation ('amber' by default). Works only with the 'hercules' and 'cga_mono' machine types. Note: You can also cycle through the available palettes via hotkeys. Possible values: amber, green, white, paperwhite.
Set the interpretation of CGA RGBI colours. Affects all machine types capable of displaying CGA or better graphics. Built-in presets:

EnumValues.Description: The canonical CGA palette, as emulated by VGA adapters (default).

Emulation of an idealised Tandy monitor with adjustable brown level. The brown level can be provided as an optional second parameter (0 - red, 50 - brown, 100 - dark yellow; defaults to 50). E.g. tandy 100
Emulation of the actual colour output of an unknown Tandy monitor.

Emulation of the actual colour output of an IBM 5153 monitor with a unique contrast control that dims non-bright colours only. The contrast can be optionally provided as a second parameter (0 to 100; defaults to 100), e.g. ibm5153 60
Palettes used by the Amiga ports of Sierra AGI games.
A mix of EGA and Amiga colours used by the Sarien AGI-interpreter.
Palette used by the Amiga ports of LucasArts EGA games.
Commodore 64 inspired colours based on the Colodore palette.
Colodore palette with 20% more saturation.
A modern take on the canonical CGA palette with dialed back contrast.

Options.Description: Set an adaptive CRT monitor emulation shader or a regular GLSL shader in OpenGL output modes. Adaptive CRT shader options: crt-auto: A CRT shader that prioritises developer intent and how people experienced the game at the time of release (default). The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

EnumValues.Description: A CRT shader that prioritises developer intent and how people experienced the game at the time of release (default). The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

A CRT shader that prioritises geometric accuracy and pixel-perfectness. The appropriate shader variant is automatically selected based the graphics standard of the current video mode and the viewport resolution, irrespective of the 'machine' setting. This means that even on an emulated VGA

Options.Description: Enable composite video emulation (disabled by default).
Era of composite technology ('auto' by default). When 'auto', PCjr uses 'new', and CGA/Tandy use 'old'. Possible values: auto, old, new.
Appearance of RGB palette. For example, adjust until the sky is blue.
Intensity of colors, from washed out to vivid.
Ratio between the dark and light area.
Luminosity of the image, from dark to light.
Convergence of subpixel elements, from blurry to sharp (CGA and Tandy-only).
CPU core used in emulation ('auto' by default). 'auto' will switch to dynamic if available and appropriate. Possible values: auto, dynamic, normal, simple.
CPU type used in emulation ('auto' by default). 'auto' is the fastest choice. Possible values: auto, 386, 386_slow, 486_slow, pentium_slow, 386_prefetch.

Number of instructions DOSBox tries to emulate per millisecond ('auto' by default). Setting this value too high may result in sound drop-outs and lags. auto: Try to guess what a game needs. It usually works, but can fail with certain games. fixed <number>: Set a fixed number of cycles. This is what you usually need if 'auto' fails (e.g. 'fixed 4000'). max: Allocate as much cycles as your computer is able to handle. Possible values: auto, fixed, max.

EnumValues.Description: Try to guess what a game needs. It usually works, but can fail with certain games.
Set a fixed number of cycles. This is what you usually need if 'auto' fails (e.g. 'fixed 4000').
Allocate as much cycles as your computer is able to handle.

Options.Description: Number of cycles added or subtracted with speed control hotkeys (10 by default).
Setting it lower than 100 will be a percentage (20 by default).
Memory size (in MB) of the 3dfx Voodoo card (12 MB as default). Possible values: disabled, 4, 12.

Performance optimisations to use when emulating the 3dfx Voodoo card: 0: No optimizations. 1: Multi-threading (default). 2: Disable bilinear filtering. 3: All optimizations (both 1 and 2). Note: Voodoo emulation is software-based and does not use host-level OpenGL calls.

EnumValues.Description: No optimizations
Multi-threading (default)
Disable bilinear filtering
All optimizations (both 1 and 2)

Options.Description: Directory where the various captures are saved, such as audio, video, MIDI and screenshot captures. ('capture' in the current working directory by default).

Set the capture format of the default screenshot action ('upscaled' by default): upscaled: The image is bilinear-sharp upscaled and the correct aspect ratio is maintained, depending on the 'aspect' setting. The vertical scaling factor is always an integer. For example, 320x200 content is upscaled to 1600x1200 (5:6 integer scaling), 640x480 to 1920x1440 (3:3 integer scaling), and 640x350 to 1400x1050 (2.1875:3 scaling; fractional horizontally and integer vertically). The filenames of upscaled screenshots have no postfix (e.g. 'image0001.png'). rendered: The post-rendered, post-shader image shown on the screen is captured. The filenames of rendered screenshots end with '-rendered' (e.g. 'image0001-rendered.png'). raw: The contents of the raw framebuffer is captured (this always results in square pixels). The filenames of raw screenshots end with '-raw' (e.g. 'image0001-raw.png'). If multiple formats are specified separated by spaces, the default screenshot action will save multiple images in the specified formats. Keybindings for taking single screenshots in specific formats are also available.

EnumValues.Description: The image is bilinear-sharp upscaled and the correct aspect ratio is maintained, depending on the 'aspect' setting. The vertical scaling factor is always an integer. For example, 320x200 content is upscaled to 1600x1200 (5:6 integer scaling), 640x480 to 1920x1440 (3:3 integer scaling), and 640x350 to 1400x1050 (2.1875:3 scaling; fractional horizontally and integer vertically). The filenames of upscaled screenshots have no postfix (e.g. 'image0001.png').
The post-rendered, post-shader image shown on the screen is captured. The filenames of rendered screenshots end with '-rendered' (e.g. 'image0001-rendered.png').
The contents of the raw framebuffer is captured (this always results in square pixels). The filenames of raw screenshots end with '-raw' (e.g. 'image0001-raw.png').

Options.Description: Set the mouse capture behaviour: onclick: Capture the mouse when clicking any mouse button in the window (default). onstart: Capture the mouse immediately on start. Might not work correctly on some host operating systems. seamless: Let the mouse move seamlessly between the DOSBox window and the rest of the desktop; captures only with middle-click or hotkey. Seamless mouse does not work correctly with all the games. Windows 3.1x can be made compatible with a custom mouse driver. nomouse: Hide the mouse and don't send mouse input to the game. For touch-screen control, use 'seamless'. Possible values: seamless, onclick, onstart, nomouse.

EnumValues.Description: Let the mouse move seamlessly between the DOSBox window and the rest of the desktop; captures only with middle-click or hotkey. Seamless mouse does not work correctly with all the games. Windows 3.1x can be made compatible with a custom mouse driver.
Capture the mouse when clicking any mouse button in the window  (default).
Capture the mouse immediately on start. Might not work correctly on some host operating systems.
Hide the mouse and don't send mouse input to the game.

Options.Description: If enabled, middle-click will release the captured mouse, and also capture when seamless (enabled by default).

Allows mouse seamless behavior and mouse pointer release to work in fullscreen mode for systems with more than one display. (enabled by default). Note: You should disable this if it incorrectly detects multiple displays when only one should actually be used. This might happen if you are using mirrored display mode or using an AV receiver's HDMI input for audio-only listening.

Mouse sensitivity for the horizontal and vertical axes, as a percentage (100,100 by default). Negative values invert the axis, zero disables it. Providing only one value sets sensitivity for both axes. The setting can be adjusted in runtime (also per mouse interface) using internal MOUSECTL.COM tool, available on drive Z.
Enable to bypass your operating system's mouse acceleration and sensitivity settings (enabled by default). Works in fullscreen or when the mouse is captured in window mode.

Enable built-in DOS mouse driver (enabled by default). Notes: - Disable if you intend to use original MOUSE.COM driver in emulated DOS. - When guest OS is booted, built-in driver gets disabled automatically.

Update mouse movement counters immediately, without waiting for interrupt (disabled by default). May improve gameplay, especially in fast-paced games (arcade, FPS, etc.), as for some games it effectively boosts the mouse sampling rate
Set the PS/2 mouse model (ps2mouse by default). Possible values:

EnumValues.Description: 3 buttons, standard PS/2 mouse.
3 buttons + wheel, Microsoft IntelliMouse.
5 buttons + wheel, Microsoft IntelliMouse Explorer.
no PS/2 mouse emulated.

Options.Description: Enable COM port mice in the [serial] section. Possible values: 2button, 3button, wheel, msm, 2button+msm, 3button+msm, wheel+msm.

EnumValues.Description: 2 buttons, Microsoft mouse.
3 buttons, Logitech mouse; mostly compatible with Microsoft mouse.
3 buttons + wheel; mostly compatible with Microsoft mouse.
3 buttons, Mouse Systems mouse; NOT compatible with Microsoft mouse.
Automatic choice between '2button' and 'msm'.
Automatic choice between '3button' and 'msm'.
Automatic choice between 'wheel' and 'msm' (default).

Options.Description: Enable silent mode (disabled by default). Sound is still fully emulated in silent mode, but DOSBox outputs silence.
Mixer sample rate (48000 by default). Possible values: 8000, 11025, 16000, 22050, 32000, 44100, 48000.
Mixer block size (1024 by default). Possible values: 256, 512, 1024, 2048, 4096, 8192, 16384.
Mixer prebuffering in milliseconds (50 by default).
Enable negotiation for the OPL chip (true by default).
Enable dynamic compression of OPL output (true by default).
Enable crossfeed emulation (off by default).

EnumValues.Description: No crossfeed (default).
Enable crossfeed (at strength 40).
Set crossfeed strength from 0 to 100, where 0 means no crossfeed (off) and 100 full crossfeed (effectively turning stereo content into mono).

Options.Description: Enable reverb emulation (off by default).

EnumValues.Description: No reverb (default).
Enable reverb (medium preset).
Simulates the sound of a small integrated speaker in a room; specifically designed for small-speaker audio systems (PC Speaker, Tandy, PS/1 Audio, and LPT DAC devices).
Adds a subtle sense of space; good for games that use a single synth channel (typically OPL) for both music and sound effects.
Medium room preset that works well with a wide variety of games.
Large hall preset recommended for games that use separate channels for music and digital audio.
A stronger variant of the large hall preset; works really well in some games with more atmospheric soundtracks.

Options.Description: Enable chorus emulation (off by default).

EnumValues.Description: No chorus (default).
Enable chorus (normal preset).
A light chorus effect (especially suited for synth music that features lots of white noise.)
Normal chorus that works well with a wide variety of games.
An obvious and upfront chorus effect.

Options.Description: Set where MIDI data from the emulated MPU-401 MIDI interface is sent ('auto' by default): oss: Use the Linux OSS MIDI playback interface. alsa: Use the Linux ALSA MIDI playback interface. fluidsynth: The built-in FluidSynth MIDI synthesizer (SoundFont player). See the [fluidsynth] section for detailed configuration. mt32: The built-in Roland MT-32 synthesizer. See the [mt32] section for detailed configuration. auto: Either one of the built-in MIDI synthesisers (if `midiconfig` is set to 'fluidsynth' or 'mt32'), or a MIDI device external to DOSBox (any other 'midiconfig' value). This might be a software synthesizer or physical device. This is the default behaviour. none: Disable MIDI output. Possible values: auto, oss, alsa, fluidsynth, mt32, none.

EnumValues.Description: Use the Linux OSS MIDI playback interface.
Use the Linux OSS MIDI playback interface.
Use the Linux ALSA MIDI playback interface.
The built-in FluidSynth MIDI synthesizer (SoundFont player). See the [fluidsynth] section for detailed configuration.
The built-in Roland MT-32 synthesizer. See the [mt32] section for detailed configuration.
Disable MIDI output.

Options.Description: Configuration options for the selected MIDI interface (unset by default). This is usually the ID or name of the MIDI synthesizer you want to use (find the ID/name with the DOS command 'MIXER /LISTMIDI'). Notes: - This option has no effect when using the built-in synthesizers (fluidsynth and mt32). - When using the built-in synthesizers, you can specify a SoundFont file to use with the 'soundfont' option in the [fluidsynth] section.
Enable MPU-401 emulation (true by default).

EnumValues.Description: Intelligent mode (default).
UART mode.
Disable MPU-401 emulation.

Options.Description: Enable raw MIDI output (false by default).
SoundFont file to use for MIDI synthesis (unset by default).
Chorus effect: 'auto' (default), 'on', 'off', or custom values.

EnumValues.Description:
When using custom values:
	All five must be provided in-order and space-separated.
	The first value is the chorus effect type (0 = off, 1 = normal, 2 = triplet).
	The second value is the chorus effect level (0-10).
	The third value is the chorus effect speed (0-10).
	The fourth value is the chorus effect depth (0-10).
	The fifth value is the chorus effect feedback (0-10).

Options.Description: Reverb effect: 'auto' (default), 'on', 'off', or custom values.

EnumValues.Description:
When using custom values:
	All five must be provided in-order and space-separated.
	The first value is the reverb effect type (0 = off, 1 = small room, 2 = medium room, 3 = large room, 4 = medium hall, 5 = large hall, 6 = plate).
	The second value is the reverb effect level (0-10).
	The third value is the reverb effect time (0-10).
	The fourth value is the reverb effect damping (0-10).
	The fifth value is the reverb effect width (0-10).

Options.Description: Filter: 'auto' (default), 'on', 'off', or custom values.

EnumValues.Description:
When using custom values:
	All three must be provided in-order and space-separated.
	The first value is the filter type (0 = off, 1 = low-pass, 2 = high-pass, 3 = band-pass).
	The second value is the filter cutoff (0-10).
	The third value is the filter resonance (0-10).

Options.Description: MT-32 model to use: auto: Pick the first available model, in order as listed. mt32: Pick the first available MT-32 model, in order as listed. cm32l: Pick the first available CM-32L model, in order as listed. mt32_old: Alias for MT-32 v1.07. mt32_new: Alias for MT-32 v2.04. Possible values: auto, cm32ln_100, cm32l_102, cm32l_100, mt32_old, mt32_107, mt32_106, mt32_105, mt32_104, mt32_bluer, mt32_new, mt32_204, mt32_207, mt32_206, mt32_203.

EnumValues.Description: Pick the first available model, in order as listed.
Pick the first available MT-32 model, in order as listed.
Pick the first available CM-32L model, in order as listed.
Alias for MT-32 v1.07.
Alias for MT-32 v2.04.

Options.Description: The directory containing ROMs for one or more models. The directory can be absolute or relative, or leave it blank to use the 'mt32-roms' directory in your DOSBox configuration directory. Other common system locations will be checked as well. ROM files inside this directory may include any of the following: - MT32_CONTROL.ROM and MT32_PCM.ROM, for the 'mt32' model. - CM32L_CONTROL.ROM and CM32L_PCM.ROM, for the 'cm32l' model. - Unzipped MAME MT-32 and CM-32L ROMs, for the versioned models.
Filter for the Roland MT-32/CM-32L audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see 'sb_filter' for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Custom filter definition; see 'sb_filter' for details.

Options.Description: Type of Sound Blaster to emulate ('sb16' by default). 'gb' is Game Blaster. Possible values: sb1, sb2, sbpro1, sbpro2, sb16, gb, none.
The IO address of the Sound Blaster (220 by default). Possible values: 220, 240, 260, 280, 2a0, 2c0, 2e0, 300.
The IRQ number of the Sound Blaster (7 by default). Possible values: 3, 5, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12.
The DMA channel of the Sound Blaster (1 by default). Possible values: 0, 1, 3, 5, 6, 7.
The High DMA channel of the Sound Blaster (5 by default). Possible values: 1, 5, 6, 7.
Enable the Sound Blaster mixer interface (true by default).
Enable the Sound Blaster warm-up sequence (true by default).
Type of OPL emulation. On 'auto' the mode is determined by sblaster type. Possible values: auto, cms, opl2, dualopl2, opl3, none.
Filter for the Sound Blaster audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Modern filter (recommended).
Old filter (for compatibility with DOSBox versions 0.74 and older).
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

Options.Description: Always apply the Sound Blaster filter, even when the OPL is disabled (false by default).
Filter for the OPL audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Modern filter (recommended).
Old filter (for compatibility with DOSBox versions 0.74 and older).
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

Options.Description: Filter for the CMS audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Modern filter (recommended).
Old filter (for compatibility with DOSBox versions 0.74 and older).
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

Options.Description: Enable the Gravis Ultrasound emulation (false by default).
The IO base address of the Gravis Ultrasound (240 by default). Possible values: 240, 220, 260, 280, 2a0, 2c0, 2e0, 300.
The IRQ number of the Gravis Ultrasound (5 by default). Possible values: 3, 5, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12.
The DMA channel of the Gravis Ultrasound (3 by default). Possible values: 0, 1, 3, 5, 6, 7.
Path to the Gravis Ultrasound directory (unset by default).
Filter for the Gravis Ultrasound audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Modern filter (recommended).
Old filter (for compatibility with DOSBox versions 0.74 and older).
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

Options.Description: Enable the IMFC (Intelligent Music For Computers) emulation (false by default).
The IO base address of the IMFC (2a20 by default). Possible values: 220, 240, 260, 280, 2a0, 2c0, 2e0, 300.
The IRQ number of the IMFC (3 by default). Possible values: 3, 5, 7, 9, 10, 11, 12.
Filter for the IMFC audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Modern filter (recommended).
Old filter (for compatibility with DOSBox versions 0.74 and older).
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

Options.Description: Model of chip to emulate in the Innovation SSI-2001 card: auto: Use the 6581 chip. 6581: The original chip, known for its bassy and rich character. 8580: A later revision that more closely matched the SID specification. It fixed the 6581's DC bias and is less prone to distortion. The 8580 is an option on reproduction cards, like the DuoSID. none: Disable the card (default). Possible values: auto, 6581, 8580, none.

EnumValues.Description: Use the 6581 chip.
The original chip, known for its bassy and rich character.
A later revision that more closely matched the SID specification. It fixed the 6581's DC bias and is less prone to distortion. The 8580 is an option on reproduction cards, like the DuoSID.
Disable the card (default).

Options.Description: The SID chip's clock frequency, which is jumperable on reproduction cards. default: 0.895 MHz, per the original SSI-2001 card (default). c64ntsc: 1.023 MHz, per NTSC Commodore PCs and the DuoSID. c64pal: 0.985 MHz, per PAL Commodore PCs and the DuoSID. hardsid: 1.000 MHz, available on the DuoSID. Possible values: default, c64ntsc, c64pal, hardsid.

EnumValues.Description: 0.895 MHz, per the original SSI-2001 card (default).
1.023 MHz, per NTSC Commodore PCs and the DuoSID.
0.985 MHz, per PAL Commodore PCs and the DuoSID.
1.000 MHz, available on the DuoSID.

Options.Description: The IO port address of the Innovation SSI-2001 (280 by default). Possible values: 240, 260, 280, 2a0, 2c0.
Adjusts the 6581's filtering strength as a percent from 0 to 100 (50 by default). The SID's analog filtering meant that each chip was physically unique.
Adjusts the 8580's filtering strength as a percent from 0 to 100 (50 by default).
Filter for the Innovation audio output: off: Don't filter the output (default). <custom>: Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Don't filter the output (default).
Modern filter (recommended).
Old filter (for compatibility with DOSBox versions 0.74 and older).
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

Options.Description: Enable PC-Speaker emulation (discrete by default).

EnumValues.Description: Waveform is created using discrete steps (default).
Waveform is created using sinc impulses.

Options.Description: Enable PC-Speaker lowpass filter (on by default).

EnumValues.Description: Enable PC-Speaker lowpass filter (on by default).
Disable PC-Speaker lowpass filter.
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Enable Tandy Sound System emulation (auto by default).
Enable Tandy Sound System emulation.
Disable Tandy Sound System emulation.

Options.Description: Enable Tandy Sound System lowpass filter (on by default).

EnumValues.Description: Enable Tandy Sound System lowpass filter (on by default).
Disable Tandy Sound System lowpass filter.
Custom filter definition; see below for details.

EnumValues.Description: Enable Tandy Sound System DAC filter (on by default).

Options.Description: Enable DAC on parallel port (none by default).

EnumValues.Description: Disable DAC on parallel port (none by default).
Enable DAC on parallel port 1.
Enable DAC on parallel port 2.

Options.Description: Enable DAC on parallel port lowpass filter (on by default).

EnumValues.Description: Enable DAC on parallel port lowpass filter (on by default).

Options.Description: Enable ReelMagic MPEG playback support (off by default).

EnumValues.Description: Disable ReelMagic MPEG playback support (off by default).
Initialize the card without loading the FMPDRV.EXE driver.
Initialize the card and load the FMPDRV.EXE on start-up.

Options.Description: Set the 32-bit magic key used to decode the game's videos (auto by default).

EnumValues.Description: Use the built-in routines to determine the key (default).
Use the most commonly found key, which is 0x40044041.
Use The Horde's key, which is 0xC39D7088.
Set a custom key in hex format (e.g., 0x12345678).

Options.Description: Override the frame rate code used during video playback (0 by default).

EnumValues.Description: No override: attempt automatic rate discovery (default).
Override the frame rate to one the following (use 1 through 7): 1=23.976

Options.Description: Type of joystick to emulate: auto: Autodetect the joystick type (default). none: Disable joystick emulation. 2axis: Emulate a 2-axis joystick. 4axis: Emulate a 4-axis joystick. fcs: Emulate a CH Flightstick. ch: Emulate a CH Flightstick Pro. thrustmaster: Emulate a Thrustmaster. tandy: Emulate a Tandy. thrustmaster_fc: Emulate a Thrustmaster Freestyler Cordless 2. gravis: Emulate a Gravis GamePad Pro. gravisgrip: Emulate a Gravis GrIP.

EnumValues.Description: Autodetect the joystick type (default).
Disable joystick emulation.
Emulate a 2-axis joystick.
Emulate a 4-axis joystick.
Emulate a CH Flightstick.
Emulate a CH Flightstick Pro.
Emulate a Thrustmaster.
Emulate a Tandy.
Emulate a Thrustmaster Freestyler Cordless 2.
Emulate a Gravis GamePad Pro.
Emulate a Gravis GrIP.

Options.Description: Enable timed intervals for axis. This is on by default. Use this option if your joystick drifts (away) from the center position.
Enable autofire for buttons. This is off by default. Use this option if your joystick button presses are not detected properly.
Swap the 3rd and the 4th axis. This is off by default. Use this if the 4th axis (usually the throttle) is not detected properly.
Enable button wrapping at the number of emulated buttons. This is off by default. Use this if your joystick buttons are not detected properly.
Enable circular joystick input. This is off by default. Use this if your joystick is not detected properly.
The size of the deadzone for joystick input. This is 10 by default. Use this if your joystick is not detected properly.
Enable hotkeys for joystick calibration. This is off by default. Use this if you want to calibrate your joystick.
The calibration value for the x-axis of the joystick. This is auto by default. Use this if your joystick is not detected properly.

EnumValues.Description: Autodetect the calibration value (default).

Options.Description: The calibration value for the y-axis of the joystick. This is auto by default. Use this if your joystick is not detected properly.

EnumValues.Description: Autodetect the calibration value (default).

Options.Description: Set type of device connected to COM port. Can be disabled, dummy, modem, nullmodem, direct ('dummy' by default). Additional parameters must be on the same line in the form of parameter:value. Parameter for all types is irq (optional). - for 'modem': listenport, sock, baudrate (all optional). - for 'nullmodem': server, rxdelay, txdelay, telnet, usedtr, transparent, port, inhsocket, sock (all optional). SOCK parameter specifies the protocol to be used by both sides of the conection. 0 for TCP and 1 for ENet reliable UDP. Example: serial1=modem listenport:5000 sock:1 Possible values: disabled, dummy, modem, nullmodem, direct.

EnumValues.Description: Fully disable serial port 1.
Use a dummy serial port 1 (default).
Use a modem on serial port 1.
Use a nullmodem connection on serial port 1.
Use a direct serial connection on serial port 1.

Options.Description: See 'serial1'.

EnumValues.Description: Fully disable serial port 2.
Use a dummy serial port 2 (default).
Use a modem on serial port 2.
Use a nullmodem connection on serial port 2.
Use a direct serial connection on serial port 2.

Options.Description: See 'serial1'.

EnumValues.Description: Fully disable serial port 3.
Use a dummy serial port 3 (default).
Use a modem on serial port 3.
Use a nullmodem connection on serial port 3.
Use a direct serial connection on serial port 3.

Options.Description: See 'serial1'.

EnumValues.Description: Fully disable serial port 4.
Use a dummy serial port 4 (default).
Use a modem on serial port 4.
Use a nullmodem connection on serial port 4.
Use a direct serial connection on serial port 4.

Options.Description: Expand shell variables in the DOSBox configuration file (auto by default).

Options.Description: File used to store the shell history ('shell_history.txt' by default).
File used to store the SETVER table ('setver_table.txt' by default).
Enable IPX over UDP/IP emulation (false by default).
Enable NE2000 Ethernet emulation (false by default).
The base address of the NE2000 card (300 by default).
The IRQ of the NE2000 card (3 by default).
The MAC address of the NE2000 card (AC:DE:48:88:99:AA by default).
Forward TCP connections from the host to the guest. The format is hostport:guestport. Example: tcp_port_forwards=80:80,443:443
Forward UDP connections from the host to the guest. The format is hostport:guestport. Example: udp_port_forwards=80:80,443:443
